bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, April 2, 1952

div1.p: Hench will inform Clark that Blossom plans to write a story about the Apache woman who worked in her parent's household. Hench offers to put her into contact with one of the editors of the Saturday Evening Post. He reports that the Cuban government seems prepared to do something about Camp Lazear, and he will send Blossom copies of the plans.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, April 2, 1952
div1.opener:
April 2, 1952
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I have your letter of March 28 and am interested indeed to hear that
Mr. Clark of William and Mary College was on the right track about the
“Indian woman”. I shall write him and tell him that you yourself are
writing a story on that. And who in the world would have a better
right than you to do this story.

Incidentally, if you are planning to write a story or two, I wonder if
you kept a copy of your tentative manuscript written some years ago
which you kindly deposited with me with the rest of your father's
data. If not, and if you wish a copy, I will send you one at once and
if, at any time, I can help you by checking any of the data that you
deposited with me, I am yours to command.

I do not have many contacts with lay magazines, but I do know one of
the chief editors of the Saturday Evening Post. I met him when he was
here three years ago to write a story on cortisone and have kept in
touch with him. His name is Steven Spencer. A year or so ago I ap-
proached him in connection with a short story that Johnny Moran had
written from Havana. At that time, unfortunately, Mr. Spencer was not
interested as he said they had carried a story on Johnny Moran about
ten years before and did not think that another one from him was ap-
propriate at this time. I do not know, therefore, how sympathetic
Mr. Spencer would be to a story about your father. In my opinion he
ought to be and certainly a story about Walter Reed written by his
daughter and/or son should have the highest priority. If I can help
in any way, please let me know.

I have been meaning to write you and your brother and will do so as soon
as I have time to write up a summary of my recent visit to Havana. At
long last the Cuban Government seems about to do something for Camp
Lazear. They plan to make a small park and a small memorial. I have
just had copied here at the Clinic the blue print plans as drawn up
by the Engineering Department of the Ministry of Sanitation. The plan
leaves some things to be desired, but nevertheless it is a start in the
right direction. I have had copies of the plans made for you and your
brother and will send them shortly.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Copy to General Reed
